Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_109071: What's the right way to set Linux kernel runtime parameters?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_109071: sysctl - configure kernel parameters at runtime

$ sudo sysctl -a | head -5
abi.vsyscall32 = 1
debug.exception-trace = 1
debug.kprobes-optimization = 1
dev.cdrom.autoclose = 1
dev.cdrom.autoeject = 0

$ sysctl -w kernel.domainname="example.com"

$ sysctl -p

Explanations about Options.-p:
Load in sysctl settings from the file specified or /etc/sysctl.conf if none given.
 Specifying - as filename means reading data from standard input. Using this option
 will mean arguments to sysctl are files, which are read in the order they are
 specified. The file argument may be specified as regular expression.

Explanations about Options.-C:
Change to directory dir before reading the makefiles or doing anything else. If
 multiple -C options are specified, each is interpreted relative to the previous one:
 -C / -C etc is equivalent to -C /etc. This is typically used with recursive
 invocations of make.

Explanations about Options.--print-architecture: Print architecture of packages dpkg installs (for example, “i386”).
Explanations about Options.--list:
List packages matching given pattern.
 -s, --status package-name...
 Report status of specified package.
 -L, --listfiles package-name...
 List files installed to your system from package-name.
 -S, --search filename-search-pattern...
 Search for a filename from installed packages.
 -p, --print-avail package-name...
 Display details about package-name, as found in
 /var/lib/dpkg/available. Users of APT-based frontends
 should use apt-cache show package-name instead.

Run the shell specified by the SHELL environment variable if it is set or the
 shell specified by the invoking user's password database entry. If a command is
 specified, it is passed to the shell for execution via the shell's -c option.
 If no command is specified, an interactive shell is executed. Note that most
 shells behave differently when a command is specified as compared to an
 interactive session; consult the shell's manual for details.
